title: 106_s2067
content: The section may be cited as the "American's Math and Science Excellence Act". The Act defines key terms such as Director, elementary school, secondary school, institution of higher education, charter school, and internship. Personal service by an individual, other than an employee, for a specified period primarily for the educational experience of the individual. SEC. 3. INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY TEACHER TRAINING GRANTS. The Director, with the Secretary of Education, can award grants for professional development in information technology for teachers in elementary, secondary, or charter schools. Grants can be awarded for up to 1 year for individuals and up to 3 years for educational institutions. To apply for a grant, individuals or institutions must submit an application to the Director as required. Grant funds awarded under this section may be used for substitute teacher pay, professional development fees, and developing a merit-based compensation system to support expert teachers in information technology. Grants under this subsection may be awarded to individual teachers, schools, or organizations supporting professional development in information technology for elementary, secondary, or charter schools. Factors considered by the Director include teaching performance and expenses related to professional development in information technology. The Director considers factors like academic performance and availability of matching funds when awarding grants for professional development in information technology for schools. $25,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2001, increasing to $35,000,000 by fiscal year 2004. SEC. 4. TWENTY-FIRST CENTURY WORKFORCE INTERNSHIP GRANTS. The Director, in consultation with the Secretary of Education, can award grants to schools and higher education institutions for student information technology internships. Applications must be submitted to the Director, and grants can be used for internships to strengthen science. The Director, in consultation with the Secretary of Education, can award grants to schools and higher education institutions for student internships in science, mathematics, engineering, information technology, manufacturing, or information security in the private sector. Grants are awarded for a maximum of 3 years, and private sector matching funds are required. Authorization of appropriations is provided to the National Science Foundation for this purpose. The National Science Foundation is authorized to receive $15,000,000 for fiscal year 2001, $20,000,000 for fiscal year 2002, $25,000,000 for fiscal year 2003, and $25,000,000 for fiscal year 2004 for student internships in various fields. Matching funds from the private sector are required for grants awarded for a maximum of 3 years. SEC. 5. INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY STATE SCHOLARSHIP PROGRAM. The Director of the National Science Foundation, in consultation with the Secretary of Education, will provide grants to States for scholarships in science, math, engineering, or related fields at the graduate level. Scholarships can be used for technology-related degree programs at accredited institutions, covering tuition and related expenses. The National Science Foundation provides grants to States for scholarships in science, math, engineering, or related fields at the graduate level. States must match at least half of the program cost with State funds and ensure that two-thirds of scholarships go to students from low-income families. $50,000,000 is authorized for grants from 2001 to 2004. SEC. 6. TWENTY-FIRST CENTURY TEACHER ENHANCEMENT PROGRAM. Amends Section 19A of the National Institute of Standards and Technology Act to create the TEACHER SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY ENHANCEMENT PROGRAM. The Director will establish a Twenty-First Century Teacher Enhancement Program within the Institute to provide professional development for math and science teachers in elementary, middle, and secondary schools. The program aims to enhance teaching strategies, self-confidence in math and science, and understanding of their impact on commerce and the economy, focusing on scientific measurements, tests and standards development, industrial competitiveness, manufacturing, and technology transfer. The Director will establish a Twenty-First Century Teacher Enhancement Program within the Institute to provide professional development for math and science teachers in elementary, middle, and secondary schools. The program will cover teaching strategies, self-confidence in math and science, and understanding their impact on commerce and the economy. It will focus on scientific measurements, tests and standards development, industrial competitiveness, manufacturing, technology transfer, and other areas of expertise determined by the Director. Selection procedures and criteria will be developed for teacher participants, with the program conducted annually during the summer months. Activities will take place at Institute laboratory facilities or through alternative methods like the Internet, video conferencing, workshops, and conferences. The National Institute of Standards and Technology will allocate funds for the Twenty-First Century Teacher Enhancement Program, with increasing amounts for fiscal years 2001 to 2004.
